name: Maintainability
description: The set of attributes that bear on the effort needed to make specified modifications to a system or service. The ease with which a system or component may be modified to correct faults, improve performance or adapt to a changed environment. The ease with which a system may be retained in, or restored to a state in which it performs its required functions.

components.name: System Modules
components.definition: knowledge and documentation of system modules

criteria.name: Knowledge of the system modules and their inter-relationships necessary to specify new features, develop new features, or perform upgrades exists - but may be organised in ad-hoc manner.  Some change development process from requirements to implementation exists but is dependent upon the skills of individuals.
Standards for documenting module boundaries (APIs, etc.) are emerging at individual team level.
Standards for documenting dependencies between modules are emerging at individual team level. Some impact assessment is performed.
Standards for documenting dependencies between modules are defined at the organisation level. Formal impact assessment is performed in a consistent manner.

components.name: Maintenance Automation
components.definition: Automated tooling being used for maintenance

criteria.name: Some maintenance automation tooling such as CI and CD, Dev Ops, containerisation, etc. is emerging.
Maintenance automation tooling such as CI and CD, Dev Ops, containerisation, etc. is defined organisation-wide and adhered to.

Standards for the development process from requirements to implementation are emerging at the individual team level. Functional and non-functional requirements and constraints are documented with some consistency.

criteria.comment: originally also included text from CRI000070
criteria.name: Templates and playbooks exist, cover the vast majority of changes, and are granular at the module level.

components.name: Metrics
components.definition: data and metrics are collected to predict change complexity

criteria.name: Data and metrics to track change lead time against estimated complexity and impact is readily available
Changes can be made to the system with predictable turnaround, and minimal risk
Goals are set for maintenance or improvement of change lead time metrics against estimated complexity and impact.

components.name: Access
components.definition: access to maintainable assets is controlled and logged

criteria.name: PR.MA-1: Maintenance and repair of organizational assets are performed and logged, with approved and controlled tools
PR.MA-2: Remote maintenance of organizational assets is approved, logged, and performed in a manner that prevents unauthorized access

questions.definition: Do you have any documentation or central knowledge repositories where the system modules details and their inter-relationships are defined? Are these documents regularly kept up to date (for instance, when implementing features or performing an upgrade)?
Who manages the changes to the API specifications (APIs) and their distribution? Who determines which API and standards will be supported? (e.g. OIDC, OAuth2.0)
Does your team maintain and follow standards, guidelines, templates, or playbooks for the development process from requirements to implementation? Are these standards defined group-wide?
Are your functional, non-functional and other requirements stored in a centralised manner?
How granular are the requirement and change specifications? E.g. do they typically get down to the module level?
How coupled are the modules in your space? Who is responsible for the documentation of the impact of change?
Are you using any data or metrics to track lead time, velocity, cycle time, code coverage, code analysis? Any other metrics such as failed deployment, testing results, escaped defects?
